title: Create a setter method to sets Connection read timeout #1228
Create a setter method to sets Connection read timeout
Incorrect Farsi parsing to plain text
Warning fixes
body:
This pull request makes several changes to fix warnings and better comply with Java best practices. This includes:

  - Adding `SerialVersionUID` fields
  - Adding type parameters where missing
  - Adding `@Override` annotations

Among several other things.

title: Proposed fix for #1218 ("Mark invalid" error message)
body:
The current parsing code gives up parsing in certain cases instead of reading more data from the underlying reader. This can cause valid markup to be misparsed. Additionally, marks can be invalidated when more data is pulled into the buffer, so marking and rewinding works unreliably.

My attempt of fixing is required some refactoring, so the various consumeXxx() methods keep going after reaching the end of the buffer, maintaining a temporary StringBuilder to hold the data seen so far. To fix marking and rewinding, all the data past the marked position is kept in the buffer when reading more data. Now the client needs to explicitly release the mark to stop it from being kept in the buffer.

Unit tests are still all green, but this definitely needs a review from someone more familiar with the project.

title: Fix to attributes case sensitivity problem.
body: In following test case attributes of second img tag are not case independent: ``` ``` Fix added to solve this problem.

Using XML parser is not a solution as we're talking about HTML. To reproduce: ``` Document doc = Jsoup.parse("

title: Duplicated attribute parsing problem
body: In case there is duplicated tag attribute Jsoup parses the last one, but Chrome browser takes the first one.

title: Websites with large amounts of data fail to parse.
body:
Currently using Jsoup on some large websites, and it throws the Mark Invalid Exception which means the bufref is negative?

I tried using both Jsoup.connect(url).get()
and Jsoup.connect(url).execute().parse()
Both cause the same exception.
```Exception in thread "main" java.io.IOException: Mark invalid
	at org.jsoup.parser.CharacterReader.rewindToMark(CharacterReader.java:132)
	at org.jsoup.parser.Tokeniser.consumeCharacterReference(Tokeniser.java:182)
	at org.jsoup.parser.TokeniserState.readCharRef(TokeniserState.java:1698)
	at org.jsoup.parser.TokeniserState.access$100(TokeniserState.java:8)
	at org.jsoup.parser.TokeniserState$2.read(TokeniserState.java:36)
	at org.jsoup.parser.Tokeniser.read(Tokeniser.java:57)
	at org.jsoup.parser.TreeBuilder.runParser(TreeBuilder.java:55)
	at org.jsoup.parser.TreeBuilder.parse(TreeBuilder.java:47)
	at org.jsoup.parser.Parser.parseInput(Parser.java:35)
	at org.jsoup.helper.DataUtil.parseInputStream(DataUtil.java:169)
	at org.jsoup.helper.HttpConnection$Response.parse(HttpConnection.java:835)
	at org.jsoup.helper.HttpConnection.get(HttpConnection.java:285)```

if anybody would like to reproduce, here are some urls which it fails to parse:
https://www.spec.org/cpu2006/results/res2014q4/
https://www.spec.org/cpu2006/results/res2012q3/
https://www.spec.org/cpu2006/results/res2014q1/

https://www.spec.org/cpu2006/results/res2014q2/
https://www.spec.org/cpu2006/results/res2012q4/
https://www.spec.org/cpu2006/results/res2011q1/


Thanks

title: selector query "*|E" not work when tag name contains upper characters and lower characters
body:
I have an XML document with tag `<ns1:MyXmlTag>` and `<ns2:MyXmlTag>`, I am trying to extract both with `doc.select("*|MyXmlTag")` , but it return nothing.

After running some test in debugger, I find that "*|MyXmlTag" was parsed to ":myxmltag" and return false while evaluating in `TagEndsWith.matches()`.

title: Jsoup 1.11.3 Connection.Response Authorization doesn't work with JRE 1.8.0_201
body:
Hi,
After changing the JRE version from 1.8.0_161 to 1.8.0_201, authorization on website stopped working, there is now an error with code 401 (not authorized). I have been working, why it has stopped. Reverting the JRE version back helped.

> org.jsoup.HttpStatusException: HTTP error fetching URL. Status=401, URL=**

fragment of stack trace:

> at org.jsoup.helper.HttpConnection$Response.execute(HttpConnection.java:776)
	at org.jsoup.helper.HttpConnection$Response.execute(HttpConnection.java:722)
	at org.jsoup.helper.HttpConnection.execute(HttpConnection.java:306)

for code:

`this.response = Jsoup
					.connect(url)
					.timeout(30000)
					.method(Connection.Method.GET)
					.userAgent(userAgent)
					.header("Authorization", "Negotiate " + authData)
					.header("DNT", "1")
					.header("Connection", "keep-alive")
					.header("Keep-Alive", "timeout=5, max=1")
					.execute();`

seems like something in new Java version has changed. Is it known issue?

Parsing encoding problem with .html() on <style> tag
body:
I have a problem parsing and then setting the _<style>_ tag.
When I do .html() and then set back the string with .html(s) I get the HTML entity < that does not work correctly in CSS.

When I do:
```
        String html = ""
                + "<html>"
                + " <head>"
                + "     <style>.outer > .inner {background-color:white;}</style>"
                + " </head>"
                + " <body>"
                + "     Example"
                + " </body>"
                + "</html>";
        Document document = Jsoup.parse(html);
        Element style = document.selectFirst("style");
        
        String s = style.html();
        //..
        style.html(s);
        
        System.out.println(document.toString());
```
I get:

```
<html>
 <head>
  <style>.outer > .inner {background-color:white;}</style>
 </head>
 <body>
   Example
 </body>
</html>
```

But I'm expecting that the style tag preserve the **>** selector or it won't work correctly.
I'm expecting that the result HTML code is:
```
<html>
 <head>
  <style>.outer > .inner {background-color:white;}</style>
 </head>
 <body>
   Example
 </body>
</html>
```

I would be happy to contribute to an eventual patch if you give me some hints.

title: Not preserving content outside head and body elements
body:
I'm using Jsoup parser. With prettyPrint option disabled, I'm loosing whitespaces between DOCTYPE definition and html tag. Also, I'm loosing whitespaces between html and head start tag.

I think the main problem is that Jsoup is not keeping whitespaces between html childs, and between document and html element.

I'm using HTML parser. Using XML parser the output is correct, so maybe HTML parser should do the same.
If not, what are the reasons?

Here is a test link: https://try.jsoup.org/~lPGQPj9gNjjfU1yN-pYRvQVfzMY

title: W3CDom.fromJsoup is loosing the original DocType
Add methods taking a Reader
body:
I'm trying to use Jsoup inside an interface that only has a `Reader` available. It was difficult for me to figure out how to do so without methods on the `Jsoup` class taking a `Reader`

Closes https://github.com/jhy/jsoup/issues/1177

title: Expand support for java.io.Reader
body:
I see that in https://github.com/jhy/jsoup/issues/463 some support for `Reader` was added: https://jsoup.org/apidocs/org/jsoup/parser/Parser.html#parseInput-java.io.Reader-java.lang.String-

However, I'm not quite sure how to use it. It looks like none of the `Jsoup.parse` methods take a reader. Would it be possible to add a new method taking a `Reader`? I'm trying to use Jsoup inside an interface that only has a `Reader` available

title: TextNode content remains empty while iterating through nodes
body:
I am using the currently latest Jsoup, 1.11.3, via Kotlin. Sample HTML, though the issue occurs with any file: ```
test

test 2

test 3
``` Kotlin code, via script mode. Use *kotlinc -cp jsoup-1.11.3.jar -script script.kts file.htm* to run. ``` import org.jsoup.* import org.jsoup.nodes.* import java.io.File val file = File(args[0]) val document = Jsoup.parse(file, "UTF-8") for (node: Node in document.body().childNodes()) { if (node is Element) { println("element: ${node.tagName()}") } if (node is TextNode) { println("textNode ${node.text()}") } } ``` Returned nodes: textNode, div, textNode. The textNodes do not contain the expected text, apart from whitespace, they are blank. Expected result: div, textNode test, p, textNode test 2, textNode test 3

title: The default value for outputSetting().prettyPrint() should be false
body: Jsoup.parse() by default creates a document with prettyPrint() enabled. Pretty printing html/xml introduces spurious whitespace characters in the output. The default should be to preserve the document structure (including character data) as much as possible so I believe the default for prettyPrint() should be false.
